questions.question: A pregnant female arrives at your hospital for her antenatal check-up. As an intern, you were required to draw her family pedigree chart while taking history. She has previously delivered full-term healthy dizygotic twins 5 years back. Which of the following symbols will you use to denote dizygotic twins in a pedigree chart?

options.A: Open circles or squares connected by a horizontal line
options.B: Open circles or squares not connected
options.C: Filled circles or squares connected by a horizontal line
options.D: Filled circles or squares not connected

questions.explanation: Dizygotic twins are denoted by open circles or squares connected by a horizontal line in a pedigree chart, indicating they are siblings who developed from two separate eggs.

questions.question: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote?
questions.explanation: The above pedigree chart denotes an autosomal recessive pattern. In the above pedigree chart, both males and females are carriers (equally affected), which indicates an autosomal pattern. Parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes), and there are no affected members in other generations. 25% of the children are normal, 50% are carriers, and only 25% are affected. This indicates a recessive pattern.

questions.question: While volunteering at the blood donation camp, Ananya came across a case of a thalassemic infant who has an AB-positive blood group. Her father is B-positive and her mother is A-positive. In order to understand more about donor eligibility to explain the concerned parents, she wishes to understand the inheritance pattern of ABO blood grouping. Can you help her out by choosing the correct option?
questions.explanation: The inheritance pattern of the ABO blood grouping system is codominance. Codominance: Gene expression and Mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive; in some cases, both of the alleles of a gene pair contribute to the phenotype - a condition called codominance. Examples include histocompatibility and ABO blood group antigens. Classification of genetic disorders: Mendelian disorders (Classic inheritance) • Autosomal dominant • Autosomal recessive • X-linked dominant • X-linked recessive. Non-Mendelian disorders (Non-classic inheritance) • Trinucleotide repeat mutations: Fragile X syndrome, Friedreich ataxia, Huntington's disease • Mutations in mitochondrial genes: MELAS, MERRF • Genomic imprinting: Angelman syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, Silver-Russell syndrome • Gonadal mosaicism. Chromosomal disorders: • Microdeletions: Cri du chat syndrome • Down's syndrome, Turner's syndrome, Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.question: An MBBS student, after attending a class on genetic disorders, noticed that a particular disorder appears in three consecutive generations of his family without any sex predilection. While drawing his pedigree chart, it also struck him that phenotypically normal family members were having healthy offspring. Based on this information, he concluded the pattern of inheritance of this disorder. What is the correct pattern?
questions.explanation: The pattern of inheritance in this genetic disorder is autosomal dominant. Points in favour: • Autosomal dominant disorders have a vertical mode of transmission (individuals of two generations are affected - parent and children affected). • It appears in three consecutive generations of a family without any sex predilection. • An affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the deleterious gene in each pregnancy. • Males and females are equally affected. Unaffected individuals do not pass on the disorder to their children. Autosomal dominant: Affected father, Unaffected mother, Affected son, Unaffected daughter.

questions.question: A young boy presented with a history of a genetic disorder. On further enquiry, his father and grandmother had the same disease as well. Prior to his birth, the doctor had counseled the father that there is a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to his offspring, irrespective of sex. Which of the following diseases is an example of this inheritance pattern?
questions.explanation: Autosomal dominance is the inheritance pattern seen in this question due to three generations of affected family members with a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to the next generation, irrespective of sex. Tuberous sclerosis is an example of an autosomal dominant (AD) disorder. Note: All Ehlers-Danlos syndrome types are autosomal dominant, except types V, VI, and VII. All types of osteogenesis imperfecta are autosomal dominant, except types II, III, and VII.

questions.question: Aryan is the first child born to parents suffering from achondroplasia. Although he is not suffering from this condition, the parents wish to know the chances of developing achondroplasia in the second child. What is the correct response?
questions.explanation: The chances of having an affected baby when both parents have achondroplasia (an autosomal-dominant disorder) is 50%. Autosomal dominant (AD) disorders are manifested in the heterozygous state. If both of the parents are affected, the chances of having an affected baby are 50% (since 50% will be 'Aa' and 25% will be 'AA', but 'AA' is usually fatal in the first few months of life, and 25% will be 'aa'). Note: Here, we consider both parents as 'Aa' (heterozygous) because 'AA' (homozygous) is usually fatal in the first few months of life. The odds of having an affected baby do not change with subsequent pregnancies. Inheritance pattern of Achondroplasia: Ova - Affected female - Dd, Unaffected offspring - Affected with achondroplasia, Affected male - Dd, Sperms - DD - Severely affected with achondroplasia (do not survive pregnancy). Note: The offspring affected could be of any sex. This is an Autosomal dominant (AD) disorder: Unaffected - Affected, heterozygous - Affected, homozygous.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy presented with short stature and delayed motor milestones. An x-ray showeda trident hand as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?183EV
questions.explanation: The x-ray shows short stubby fingers, with a separation between middle and ring fingers. This iscalled a trident hand and is seen in achondroplasia.AchondroplasiaIt is an autosomal-dominant chondrodysplasia and the most common condition characterized bydisproportionate short stature. It is caused by mutations in the gene coding for fibroblast growthfactor receptor type 3 (FGFR3).Clinical features (see image below):Short stature, extreme joint laxity, bowing of legs, macrocephaly, frontal bossing, midfacialhypoplasia, small chest, redundant skin folds, recurrent infections, cor pulmonale, and restrictivepulmonary disease196Radiological features• Champagne glass pelvic inlet••• Trident handShortening of tubular bones with metaphyseal flaring.• Chevron deformity

questions.question: A 14-year-old child presented with multiple hyperpigmented lesions of around size 15-20 mmin the trunk and extremities. Similar lesions of size 2-3 mm were found in his axillary andinguinal regions. A photograph of his eye showing a characteristic lesion is shown below.What is the likely diagnosis?184
questions.explanation: The features of cafe-au-lait macules, axillary and inguinal freckling along with Lisch nodulespoints toward a diagnosis of neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1).The multiple hyperpigmented lesions of more than 15 in the trunk and extremities are known ascafe-au-lait macules (>5mm in prepubertal, >15mm in postpubertal) and are present in100% of NF1 cases. The lesions of around 2-3mm in the axillary and inguinal regions are knownas axillary/inguinal freckling and are pathognomonic of NF1. The given image shows discretenodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patientswith NF-1. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas.Neurofibromatosis: It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome with the followingtypes-Axillary freckling is shown in the image below-NF1 (von Recklinghausen disease)NF2 (Central neurofibromatosis)Mutation on chromosome17Mutation on chromosome22197NF1 (von Recklinghausen disease)2 or more of the following should be present:6 or more café-au-lait spots2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuromaFreckling in the axillary or inguinal region2 or more Lisch nodules Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial boneA first degree relative with NF1Optic gliomasNF2 (Central neurofibromatosis)Predisposes to multiple tumours of the nervous system.Most commonarebilateral vestibular schwannomas; intracranial and spinal meningiomas,gliomas, neurofibromas, andposterior subcapsular lenticular opacities. Vestibular schwannomas are benign tumours that arise from the intracanalicular segment of theinferiordivision of the vestibulocochlear nerve.Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle can lead to an"ice cream cone"appearance inMRI.DAILYRO UNOS

questions.question: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1?

options.C: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.explanation: In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:• Six or more café-au-lait macules•Axillary or inguinal freckling•Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)•Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma• A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia•• Optic gliomas198• A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

questions.question: Consider the following statements about café- au- lait macules associated withneurofibromas:

options.A: Statements A, C and E true, B and D false
options.B: Statements B and C true, A, D and E false
options.C: Statements B, D and E true, A and C false
options.D: Statements A and B true, C, D and E false

questions.explanation: Statement C: The spots are scattered over the body surface, with a predilection for the trunk andextremities; sparing the face.Statement D: For diagnosis, the macules should be >5 mm in prepubertal and >15 mm inpostpubertal individuals.Statement E: 6 or more spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosisCafé-au-lait macules:•Hallmark of neurofibromatosis, present in around 100% of the patients.• 6 or more café-au-lait spots should be present for the clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosisalong with other criteria.• Present at birth, but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first fewyears of life.Note:Other diseases associated with multiple café-au-lait spots: Ataxia telangiectasia, Bloom syndrome,Fanconi's anaemia, McCune-Albright syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Maffucci syndrome, Huntersyndrome.Other neurocutaneous syndromes:•Sturge-Weber syndrome: port-wine stain over the trigeminal distribution, contralateralhemiparesis, focal seizures contralateral to the side of facial capillary malformations, calcificationof the cerebral cortex, mental retardation, and congenital glaucoma• von Hippel-Lindau disease: retinal angiomas; cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas•Ataxia telangiectasia⚫ Tuberous sclerosis•Café-au-lait spots are shown in the image given below:199DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: A 9-month-old child presents with a history of a condition seen in the image below. Onexamination, a characteristic raised skin lesion of orange peel consistency known as shagreenpatch is present in his lumbosacral region. Which one of the following is not seen in thisautosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome?185M
questions.explanation: Optic glioma is not seen in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis/Bourneville-Pringle Disease isan autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which may present during infancy withinfantile spasms (as seen in the image), and has the characterisitic skin lesion known as shagreenpatch.It is characterized by Vogt's triad (EPILOA), which includes• Epilepsy• Low intelligence (IQ)• Adenoma sebaceumThe most common manifestations are skin lesions such as ashleaf (hypomelanotic) macules,adenoma sebaceum, shagreen patch, confetti lesions, and periungual fibromas. Koenen's tumours(periungual fibromas) are small fleshy tumors that grow under the toe nails/finger nails.Cortical tubers and subependymal nodules are the characteristic brain lesions. Other lesionsinclude bilateral renal angiomyolipomas, facial angiofibroma, cardiac rhabdomyoma, and retinalhamartomas.Vigabatrin is the first-line therapy for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis.Note: Drug of choice for infantile spasms: adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)Image below: Adenoma sebaceum200Image below: Shagreen patchImage below: Periungual fibromaDAILYROUNDSDAILY ROUNDS201DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: The first child of a normal healthy couple was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. The parentsare anxious and wish to seek advice for future pregnancies. What is the percentage of chancesfor the second child to be affected?
questions.explanation: Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease has a 25% chance ofaffecting the offspring.•If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes):25% chance of normal genotype• 50% chance of carriers• 25% chance of homozygousIn autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has ahomozygous state, which means each child has a 25% chance of being affected by the disease.Note:There are 2 alleles for this, say for example "A" = normal allele and "a" = abnormal allele. So, ifeach parent is phenotypically normal and their child is affected, then they are carriers, i.e., "Aa".So, each parent has a 0.5 (50%) probability of passing the affected allele to the next generation.Also, having each child is an independent event, and the chance that the child receives anabnormal allele from the father (0.5), as well as a mother (0.5), is equal to 0.5 x 0.5 = 0.25 i.e.25%.202Autosomal recessiveCarrierfatherUnaffectedAffectedCarrierCarriermotherUnaffectedsonCarrierdaughterCarriersonaffecteddaughter

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman is homozygous for an autosomal-recessive gene and her husband isheterozygous for the same. They are planning to start a family and wish to know the outcomeof their pregnancy. Which out of the following options correctly represent the percentages ofthe outcome?

options.B: No child affected, but all are carriers186

questions.explanation: If the husband is heterozygous and the wife is homozygous for an autosomal recessive gene, 50%of the children will be affected; the rest will be carriers.This is pseudo-dominant inheritance, which refers to the observation of apparent dominant(parent to child) transmission of a known autosomal-recessive disorder, or it can also mean theinheritance of a recessive trait mimics a dominant pattern.This occurs when a homozygous affected individual has a partner who is a heterozygous carrier,and their children have a 1 in 2 chance to get affected (50%).MPseudo-dominanceHomozygousOMARROW203||N||Heterozygous

questions.question: What is the mode of inheritance of Menke's disease?
questions.explanation: The mode of inheritance of Menke's disease is X-linked recessive.X-linked recessive disorders have the following features:• Males are affected more commonly and more severely than females.•• Female carriers have a 25% risk for having an affected son, a 25% risk for a carrier daughter,and a 50% chance of having a child that does not inherit the mutated X-linked gene.•The affected father will have all daughters (100%) to be carriers and unaffected sons becausethey pass their X chromosome to all of their daughters and their Y chromosome to all of theirsons.X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance is shown in the image given below:Kinky hair disease (Menkes disease)X-linked recessiveMutation of copper-transporting, P-type adenosine triphosphatase 7A leading tocopperdeficiencyLowserum copper and ceruloplasmin levelsWilson's diseaseAutosomal recessiveMutation of adenosine triphosphatase 7B on chromosome13q14 leading toexcessivecopper accumulation.Lowceruloplasmin levels; lowserum-free copper levels andincreased urinary copper excretion

questions.question: A 41-year-old father of two has an X-linked genetic disorder. His daughter is a carrier for thesame and his son is unaffected. His wife is healthy with no inherited disease. Which of thefollowing is an example of this disorder?
questions.explanation: X-linked recessive inheritanceUnaffectedfatherXYCarriermotherXYXXXXXYUnaffectedsonUnaffecteddaughterCarrierdaughterAffectedsonUnaffectedAffectedCarrierMARROW204The mode of inheritance is X-linked recessive and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an example ofsuch a genetic disorder.

questions.question: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder?
questions.explanation: Color blindness is primarily inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. The genes for color vision arelocated on the X chromosome.Males have a single X chromosome inherited from mothers. If the X chromosome inheritedcarries a mutation, males exhibit the disease. However, females become carriers of the colorblindness gene and have a 50% chance of passing it on to their children.Female carriers usually are protected because of the random inactivation of one X chromosome.But there is a possibility that the mutant X chromosome remains active if the normal alleles areinactivated in some of the cells so the heterozygous female can express the disorder partially.The image shows the pattern of X-linked inheritance:X-linked recessive inheritanceUnaffectedfatherXYCarriermotherXYXXXXXYUnaffectedsonUnaffecteddaughterCarrierdaughterAffectedsonUnaffectedAffectedCarrierMARROWIn color blindness, the mechanism to appreciate one or more primary colors is either defective(anomalous) or absent (anopia). It may be congenital or acquired. Congenital color blindness canbe dyschromatopsia (defective color vision of any one of the RGB colors) or achromatopsia(complete color blindness of all three RGB colors). RGB colors are red, green, and blue.Tests for color blindness include the Ishihara test, Hardy-Rand-Rittler test, andFarnsworth-Munsell 100-hue test.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia?

options.B: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.explanation: Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) or Louis-Bar syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder.205The defect in AT is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11q22-23. The ATM gene is involvedin the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to combinedimmunodeficiency (impaired immunoglobin isotype switching and association with thymichypoplasia) and predisposition to an increased risk of lymphoreticular tumors such as lymphomaor leukemia.AT is characterized by progressive ataxia (beginning during infancy), telangiectasia (initially onbulbar conjunctiva), sinopulmonary infections, hypogonadism, sensitivity to ionizing radiation,insulin resistance, and raised alpha-fetoprotein levels.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness showing the followingfinding. It was found that the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. He wasdiagnosed with a hereditary muscular disorder. What is the mode of inheritance in thisdisorder?
questions.explanation: This clinical vignette includes an image of a child with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles alongwith a history of inability to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen inDuchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy:• Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease.• X-linked recessive mutations of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.Clinical features:•• Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment⚫ In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs• Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm• Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to fibrofatty replacement of muscle•Gower's sign: Patients use their arms and hands to walk up their own body from a squattingposition due to the reduced strength in the proximal muscles(hip &thigh) of the lower limbs.• Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle• Inability to walk develops by the age of 10-14 years.•Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia afteranaesthesia.•• Death occurs by 3rd decade of life due to respiratory failure.Note:Becker's Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) vs. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)Mnemonic-• BMD: Badly makes dystrophin (defective)• DMD: Does not make dystrophin (absent)206Gower's sign©MARROW

questions.question: Your second cousin, Prakriti, has been recently diagnosed with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.Your relatives are worried and keep calling you to confirm the new information that they readon the internet. In an attempt to settle their doubts about the credibility of online resources,you inform them that all of the following are true except:

options.B: Atopic dermatitis and eczema during infancy188

questions.explanation: IgM is decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, not increased. It is a rare geneticimmunodeficiency that keeps a child's immune system from functioning properly. It also makes itdifficult for a child's bone marrow to produce platelets, making a child prone to bleeding. Thissyndrome is associated with decreased IgM, increased IgA, and increased IgE levels.Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:Mnemonic WAXTIE••WA: Wiskott-Aldrich• X: X-linked recessive⚫T: Thrombocytopenia• I: Infections•• E: Eczema

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl has been diagnosed with a genetic disorder that follows a Mendelian patternof inheritance illustrated by the pedigree chart below. Which of the following can be a likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given pedigree chart illustrates an inheritance pattern that is suggestive of an X-linkeddominant disorder. Hence, hypophosphatemic rickets, which is an X-linked dominant disorder, isa likely diagnosis here.X-linked dominant disorders:•• Females are affected twice as often as males.• An affected female has a 50% probability of transmitting the disorders to her son or daughter.• An affected male transmits the disorder to all of his daughters and none of his sons.207• Some X-linked dominant conditions are lethal in a high percentage of males, e.g., incontinentiapigmenti.Other options:• Lesh-Nyhan syndrome: X-linked recessive disorder affects young boys due to the deficiency ofHGPRT enzyme in the purine pathway. It is marked by compulsive self-mutilation of the head andhands, together with learning difficulties and involuntary muscular movements.•• Fabry disease: X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease due to the deficiencyof alpha-galactosidase A. Affected males have angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, acroparesthesias,and corneal-lenticular opacities.Note:Mnemonic to remember X-linked dominant disorders: Ribbons For All Children•• Ribbons - Rett's syndrome/ Hypophosphatemic Rickets• For - Fragile X tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS)•-All Alport syndrome• Children Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease-

questions.question: A 3-year-old girl presented with poor growth and social interaction as well as midline.stereotypical movements of the hands as seen in the image below. The gene involved in Rett's syndrome is the MeCP2 gene located on the X chromosome(Xq28 predominantly of paternal origin).Rett's syndrome:•• Almost always affects girls (X- linked dominant)• Development may proceed normally until 1 year of age slowing down to the extent of regression.•• After 1 year of age, rapid regression in language and hand skills, motor milestones, and acquiredmicrocephaly become apparent.•Clinical features can include repetitive hand wringing movements, ataxia, breathing dysfunction,bruxism, scoliosis, and profound mental retardation.●Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients.Note:• Rb: Retinoblastoma: 13 chromosome•• P53: Li-Fraumeni syndrome, Sarcomas: 17• NF1: Neurofibromatosis 1-17••• NF2: Neurofibromatosis 2-22• WT1: Wilms's tumour: 11• FGFR3: Achondroplasia208

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. Onexamination, his IQ was 45 and a previous report in his records show a trinucleotide repeatmutation of CGG. Which of the following is not seen in it?
questions.explanation: In fragile-X syndrome, there would be a small nose, not large.• Fragile X syndrome or Martin-Bell syndrome: Trinucleotide repeat mutation of CGG.209Remember mnemonic Hello Mr. FRAGILE X Syndrome:• Hello: Hyperextensible joint or high-arched palate••• Mr: Mitral valve prolapse⚫ F: FMR1 P deficiency (fragile X mental retardation 1 protein) - upregulates the metabotropicglutamate receptor (mGluR) 5 pathway and alters the expression of matrix metalloproteinase(MMP) 9.⚫R: Repeating the sequence of 3 nucleotides CGG, recurrent otitis media.•••• A: Autism/Attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder/AnxietyG: Giant brain (macrocephaly) and giant testis (macroorchidism)• I: Intellectual disability, i.e., mental retardation•L: Long face with a large mandible⚫E: Everted ear• X: X-linked disorder (controversial as to whether it is X-linked dominant or recessive)The most common genetic cause of mental retardation is Down's syndrome > Fragile XSyndrome.Sherman's paradox: Risk of expressing mental retardation in fragile X syndrome increases in latergenerations (anticipation).Fragile X-associated tremor or ataxia: Intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia, which mayprogress to parkinsonism.Note:Inhibitors of the mGluR (overexpressed in fragile X) are undergoing clinical trials. questions.question: As a participant in the Indian Academy of Paediatrics quiz, you are asked to mark the type ofinheritance in MELAS. The pedigree chart shown in the image below is provided to explainwhich family members may be affected (coloured in red). Which of the following will youchoose?
